awd_titl_txt: American Geophysical Union (AGU) Chapman Conference on Advances in Understanding Alfven Waves in the Sun and the Heliosphere; Berlin, Germany; May 28-June 2, 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
Alfvén waves in space plasmas have been studied for several decades. They have been recorded in the magnetospheres of planets (e.g., Earth, Jupiter), the solar wind, as well as the solar atmosphere. Despite the great differences in the plasma properties of these regions, the overarching themes of research are wave generation, wave propagation, and wave dissipation, which are three fundamental aspects of any kind of waves. A fourth aspect of waves is their application, either with direct benefit to humans or for scientific pursuit. This grant funds support for an international conference focusing on research in Alfven waves. Support includes travel for student and early career scientists to participate and present at the conference. An AGU monograph and a special issue of a journal are planned for disseminating the results presented.

The Chapman Conference on Advances in Understanding Alfven Waves in the Sun and the Heliosphere will be held in Berlin, Germany from May 28-June 2, 2023. This interdisciplinary conference aims to bring together scientists from different communities to review and discuss the current state of research on Alfven waves in space plasmas, including the solar atmosphere, the solar wind, planetary magnetospheres and ionospheres, and laboratory plasmas (if relevant to space plasmas). Two prior wave-related Chapman conferences focused on ultra-low frequency waves (Magnetospheric ULF waves in 2005, Low-frequency waves in space plasmas in 2014). While the first one focused on waves in Earth’s magnetosphere, the second one was interdisciplinary, including waves in the solar atmosphere and other planetary magnetospheres (e.g., Jupiter, Mars).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An international and interdisciplinary Chapman conference on the topic of Alfven waves in our Solar System was held on 28 May-2 June 2023, with over 90 scientists. The conference poster is attached. An up-to-date look on where research on Alfven waves, a form of wave energy, stands was given and unanswered questions were identified for future work. The breadth of topics covered in this interdisciplinary format stimulated cross-disciplinary discussions among scientists specializing in all aspects of research related to Alfven waves in space plasmas and was an excellent opportunity for various communities to meet and learn from each other. This resulted in potential collaborations among scientists. The funds of this NSF grant were used to support travel of students and early-career scientists, enabling them to attend this conference, who otherwise would not have been able to. It should be stressed that the attendance of students is of great importance for various reasons. Students learned from their senior peers through their presentation and through many discussions for which ample time was allocated during the conference week. Students were able to also present their own work and exchange ideas with more senior scientists. Younger students also learned what a science conference is like and how to present scientific results which is vital for a successful career in academia. In addition, all the conference participants brought the energy and enthusiasm for a very successful conference.

 

To collect the discussions and results from the conference for the broader space science community, we compiled a monograph with the title "Alfven Waves across Heliophysics: Progress, Challenges, and Opportunities" with 13 chapters, covering key locations in our Solar System: ionospheres and magnetospheres of Earth, the inner planets, the outer planets; and the Sun’s atmosphere. The book cover and the table of content are attached. Each chapter was written by an expert on the specific topic at hand. All chapter topics were carefully chosen to allow for a coherent book. We will later advertise this book in scientific newsletters and advertise it at AGU meetings and possibly other meetings as well.   This conference was led by Conveners, Andreas Keiling and  Tom Van Doorsselaere.
